geeklist.title: Aussie Mid Year Maths Trade 2014
geeklist.description:
Welcome to the Aussie Mid Year Maths Trade 2014.
This is proudly brought you by the same old team. Participants please read and adhere to the rules.
[b][size=14]Rules:[/size][/b]
:d10-1: This trade is open to Australian BGGers only.
:d10-2: This trade is open to board games, expansions, card games, game accessories, RPG, video games and the like. Please don't add anything else. If you intend to allow a game to be exchanged for cash (i.e. you're selling), include the amount you will accept for it in the price. You may consider compare current market prices (ebay, BGG market, local shop). The cash value is for the MT purpose only, so any off MT dealings are person to person.
:d10-3: Golden rule: [b][size=11]SENDER PAYS SHIPPING[/size][/b]. Even if you're selling a game for cash, or you post from Perth to Townsville or Hobart. So, make sure you set your price high enough that you would be happy to pay shipping to anywhere else in Australia out of that money. By posting an item to this list you are agreeing that you can and will mail it anywhere in Australia at your expense. Avoid any conditional trades (such as pick up only at BorderCon, etc).
:d10-4: Items included in the maths trade are expected to remain as part of the maths trade until the closing date. [b][COLOR=#FF0033]If your intention is to sell an item there are other alternatives in BGG to do so[/COLOR][/b]. If an item is not longer available for whatever reason, please DELETE it. [size=10]If you decide to drop an item from the list, please do so [u]before the due date of the game submission deadline[/u].[/size] List order will be as per submissions. Note: your items could end up with a different item number due to deletions, so please check the official after the geeklist has been closed. Refer to the deadlines below.
[COLOR=#FF0033][size=12]After closure of item submissions, DON"T DELETE your items. If you don't want to trade them anymore, simple submit an empty want list.[/size][/COLOR]
:d10-5: Provide as much details as possible (edition, language, sleeved cards, game condition, etc). Pick a picture that represents the game you're offering if there are multiple versions or publishers. If necessary, take a picture of the game, upload it to your gallery, and use that image. Feel free to use the game condition rating previously suggested by petegs to describe your items:
[b]New in shrink[/b] - which means never opened. [b]Opened but unpunched[/b] - I've looked at the game but not punched counters yet or stickered blocks etc. [b]Opened and punched[/b] - Looked at, even punched counters etc but haven't played. [b]Opened and played[/b].
Count pieces to make sure the games are complete, and accurately list any components that are missing or damaged. Please look at your trade pile to make sure the game is really there. In order to make your items more (or less) appealing, you may want to add one or more "sweeteners" to the item listing -- an expansion, a related game, or a completely unrelated item that you think will make it a more desirable package. Items for which there is no BGG listing can be listed as Miscellaneous Game Accessory.
:d10-6: Cash option is available. Australian BGG registered users can participate even without submitting an item to the trade with the cash option by submitting want list before the due date.
:d10-7: Maths Traders will not be required to add cash value to the geeklist - that will be handled in the want lists. In the case that a buyer offers more than a seller is asking, the buyer will pay the seller's price.
:d10-8: There is no limit of items to be submitted in this trade. Duplicates of items already on the list are fine. Traders can combine multiple games into one item (e.g. 7 Wonders plus expansions).
:d10-9: Keep comments for listed items to a minimum. There is a separate thread for any ad hoc messages. Also, refer to the BGG forum conditions and adhere your responses to them.
:d10-1::d10-0: [b][size=12]Deadlines:[/size][/b]
Add items to the list by: [size=10][-]10pm Saturday 10 May 2014[/-][/size]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time.
Official item list posted by: [b][size=14]10pm Tuesday 13 May 2014[/size][/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time.
Want Lists due by: [b]10pm Friday 16 May 2014[/b]. EST (SYD/CBR) Australian Time.
[COLOR=#000099][b]Want list submission via GeekMail to[/b] [/COLOR]
[user=Friendless][/user]
Official Results posted at Friendless discretion from during weekend 17-18 May 2014.
No extensions for deadlines above will be granted. For respect to your fellow Maths Traders and to have enough time as people may need to get their games to a willing 'games mule' attending BorderCon 2014.
[b]Wiki:[/b]
If you require further details about Maths Trade information and how to prepare your want list, please refer to the [geekurl=/wiki/page/Aussie_Maths_Trade#]Assie Math Trade wiki[/geekurl].
If you would like to post comments about the MT the thread is below:
[geekurl=/thread/1162755/aussie-mid-year-maths-trade-2014]Aussie Mid Year MT Thread[/geekurl]
Thank you all for your participation.
[size=18][b]The Maths Trade is now CLOSED[/b][/size]
geeklist.comment:
Reserve for future announcements.
[b]Announcements:[/b]
:nuclear: MT will close Saturday 10 May 2014 at 2200 sharp.
:nuclear: Not sure about how the MT works, check [geekurl=/wiki/page/Aussie_Maths_Trade#]HERE[/geekurl]
:nuclear: Maths Trade CLOSED. No further deletion of items please!
:nuclear: Additional information can be added as comments in trade items until Tuesday.
Reserved for future reservations about future anouncements

If like me, you only want to know when new items are added to the list, or updated, rather than following the commentary, you will need to both subscribe to the list and edit your subscription.
Having subscribed to the list, select the drop down option of [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/subscription/edit/feed/geeklist/172859]edit[/url]
Under the options, next to "Comments" select "NO" and then save your selection. From this point your subscription should make more sense.

Can I please request that people not replace their entries with new games (see items #1, 8, 11). Please just delete the old item and post a new entry. On page 1 it's not a big deal, but it will be a pain to have to comb every page of the list to check for changed entries. Plus, I imagine that people who thumbed the original item will then have the new item thumbed still. Thanks.

item.comment: It sells for $34 at Milsims, Kon. I like this game a lot, it reminds me of Puerto Rico but not quite so cut-throat. It's definitely *worth* $40.

[q="Friendless"]It sells for $34 at Milsims, Kon. I like this game a lot, it reminds me of Puerto Rico but not quite so cut-throat. It's definitely *worth* $40.[/q]
$67.50 at Milsims at the moment, so I reckon it's definitely worth $40 now. Bargain.
Fair enough, $40 is indeed a bargain.

Price has changed a lot with this one. Milsims had a stack of them going cheap that no-one seemed to want - quite crazy. It is an excellent game, but doesn't fit in with FFG's usual theme-heavy games. I think that's why many people have missed it. Many Euro-enthusiasts seem to have passed it over because FFG are not their "usual" publisher.

item.comment: Is the intent of providing a cash amount to say that you'll only accept cash? or perhaps to let people know that this will be traded for something worth $60? or something else entirely.
The way I read it is that James will be accepting offers of $60 or more as well as game trade offers. In the long run it may trade for a game or it may trade for cash.
Indeed. It's purely for the benefit of people who are wanting to swap cash for games - they know the sort of offer I will be looking for on my want list.

[q="revgiblet"]Indeed. It's purely for the benefit of people who are wanting to swap cash for games - they know the sort of offer I will be looking for on my want list.[/q] ah, so that's the crucial piece of knowledge. It indicates the "sort of offer".. so it doesn't replace the want list thing, it just shows people, that if you place a cash amount against this game, you should make it at least this amount for the trade to go ahead.
thanks for clearing it up guys.

[q="balzi"]it just shows people, that if you place a cash amount against this game, you should make it at least this amount for the trade to go ahead.[/q] It doesn't necessary end up always meaning precisely that either. Because of how the math trade can incorporate cash as just one of many steps in a complex trade loop, it's possible that the recipient of the game could have a lower cash offer (going to another trade participant entirely) and still receive the game.
It really only indicates what you could pre-trade the game for (if the person listing is willing to do that), and what the user is likely to put as a cash value against the item in their own want list.

[q="balzi"][q="revgiblet"]Indeed. It's purely for the benefit of people who are wanting to swap cash for games - they know the sort of offer I will be looking for on my want list.[/q] ah, so that's the crucial piece of knowledge. It indicates the "sort of offer".. so it doesn't replace the want list thing, it just shows people, that if you place a cash amount against this game, you should make it at least this amount for the trade to go ahead.
thanks for clearing it up guys.[/q] FYI when you write your wants list you can say I want x game in exchange for y game OR $z.

item.body:
Opened, played twice. Excellent condition.
[b]Will accept cash:[/b] $35

Original boxed copy. The game is complete, with rulebooks and all the tokens, terrain pieces, and even the extra arms/weapons for all the miniatures. All the contents are in very good condition, with the following exceptions:
-Most of the cardboard terrain pieces have a stripe of tape along the edges where they attach to the plastic bulkheads - this was done to prevent fraying, and the tape is mostly concealed when the terrain is assembled, but it's probably a downer for collectors nonetheless.
-There is 15cm tear in the front face of the box cover. This was present when I bought the last copy from a GW store all those many years ago, and is not an indication of mistreatment. The box has never been crushed.
-The models, though unpainted, do each have a number painted on the edge of the base in primer. I doubt this will be a problem for anyone.
I would also include one leader and one heavy (white metal) for each of the two factions included in the box (Orlock and Goliath) bringing the total number of minis up to 28. There is also an "Imperial Bastion" that is assembled from the same plastic bulkheads and cardboard as the other terrain, and makes a good extra terrain piece.
[b]Will accept cash:[/b] $185

[thing=472][/thing] [b]plus[/b] [thing=1143][/thing] [ImageID=184398inline] [ImageID=115311inline] These are the 1980s Games Workshop releases, not the more recent FFG releases. DungeonQuest is in excellent condition for its age. All miniatures are unbroken and unpainted, and the game is complete bar some plastic counters that are easily substituted, and one non-essential card (of which there are duplicates anyway). Warrior Knights is missing a couple of non-essential paper counters (there are multiples of these, and it's unlikely you'll need all of them unless you're totally dominating the map, in which case you can probably substitute).
[b]Will accept cash:[/b] $35
item.comment: Does Dungeonquest have Heroes and/or Catacombs expansions?

In need of some TLC but hey its 30+ years old.
The box is very shelf worn, no splits so still solid, but definately shows its age.
There is no copy of the rules, nor is there an AST sheet, however both are easily printable from BGG. http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/91498/civilization-rules http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/58743/redesigned-ast
Egypt is missing 1 unit token. Illyria is missing 1 unit token. Thace is missing 1 unit token and 1 city. Should be easy enough to print decent replacement pieces. Even without its fully playable up to 6 players as is.
Board has some very slight warping but a flat surface and some heavy books should sort that.
OK thats full disclosure done.
Despite all of the above i wont be trading this lightly. This game is an absolute beast of epic proportions. Its no ameritrash or 60 min engine thash, its one of the best designed stratergy games ever IMO. However it is very long, too long for me to get a game in anymore :( a full game is 5 to 12 hours my longest being run over 2 days, worth every second. Hopefully someone else can give it the love it desirves.

In pretty good condition for a game published in 1995. Box is showing normal signs of age. The rulebook, sourcebook, terrain pieces, minis and tokens are all in great condition. The game is almost complete, except for the following missing bits:
[b]Plastic minis[/b] - 2 of the 12 plastic Orlock Fighters are missing. One I replaced with an [geekurl=/image/322632/necromunda][u]unpainted Orlock Heavy[/u][/geekurl]. I have searched around, there are plenty of the original plastic (and metal) minis for sale on ebay. The Goliath Fighters are complete (12) and I have included an extra unpainted Goliath Heavy.
[b]Plastic Bulkhead[/b] - 1 of the 30 [geekurl=/image/1415782/necromunda][u]grey plastic bulkeads[/u][/geekurl] is missing. Once again there are plenty of spares available online.
[b]Red plastic range ruler[/b] - 1 of the 2 [geekurl=/image/214722/necromunda][u]red plastic range rulers[/u][/geekurl] is missing.
[b]Cardboard L-shaped walk-way[/b] - Can not find the L-shaped cardboard walk-way piece.
Today I have successfully stripped my terrible teenage paint job from the plastic minis using [geekurl=/blogpost/17505/how-to-strip-paint-with-dettol][u]this guide on the geek[/u][/geekurl]. They came up really well :). I also have lots of extra arms and weapons still unpunched for customising your gang.
I have asked my poor mother to look through some of my stuff at her place to try and find the missing pieces. If they turn up I will certainly ship them.
[b]Trade or cash offers accepted[/b]

item.comment: I don't believe this conforms with the rules or the spirit of the math trade. The variable pricing based on shipping doesn't fit with rule 3: sender pays shipping.
Price is $250 including shipping, less if you pick it up at BorderCon (better for me). Simplez.

[q="Addicted2EuroGames"]Price is $250 including shipping, less if you pick it up at BorderCon (better for me). Simplez.[/q] But the person paying and the person receiving the game are not necessarily likely to be the same person.
It's a cash sale only - not trade - and I edited my listing to make it look more like everyone elses

From the looks of it though, it seems like you are looking to simply sell things to an individual buyer, rather than enter the item into a trade loop. Of course I could be wrong, and perhaps there are people who are willing to front $250 for some of the other items involved in the math trade. But that seems somewhat unlikely though. Which makes this look like using the math trade geeklist as a platform for a sale.

[q="paralipsis"]From the looks of it though, it seems like you are looking to simply sell things to an individual buyer, rather than enter the item into a trade loop. Of course I could be wrong, and perhaps there are people who are willing to front $250 for some of the other items involved in the math trade. But that seems somewhat unlikely though. Which makes this look like using the math trade geeklist as a platform for a sale.[/q]
I'm confused then. MANY other people seem to be listing games that are just for sale, not for trade. I believe the rules state that this method is in fact very justified and is in the spirit of the maths trade. Thanks for trying to help me. I'm new at this. :)

[q="Addicted2EuroGames"][q="paralipsis"]From the looks of it though, it seems like you are looking to simply sell things to an individual buyer, rather than enter the item into a trade loop. Of course I could be wrong, and perhaps there are people who are willing to front $250 for some of the other items involved in the math trade. But that seems somewhat unlikely though. Which makes this look like using the math trade geeklist as a platform for a sale.[/q]
I'm confused then. MANY other people seem to be listing games that are just for sale, not for trade. I believe the rules state that this method is in fact very justified and is in the spirit of the maths trade. Thanks for trying to help me. I'm new at this. :)[/q]
It's not the act of selling that's the issue, rather the fact that you are unlikely to move that item at that price.
You see Math Trades work like this: You send your game to person A, who sends theirs to person B, who sends theirs to Person C.... eventually person X sends you $250. Person X is usually not Person A, hence there needs to be someone willing to put $250 up for another game that is as valuable as yours.
Most likely that ONLY way you'll get this to trade is by a 1-1 swap of game for cash (ie a sale). Hence why use a Math Trade? Just list it on the marketplace or eBay.

Rule :d10-4: seems pretty clear here:
[q]If your intention is to sell an item there are other alternatives in BGG to do so. [/q]

I'm a newbie too this year (hey Jules) and trying to figure out what is quite a complex and mysterious thing - I've passed on the last 2-3 years worth of list through sheer frustration at not getting the "essence" of it all - but given my attendance at BorderCon, I'm determined to make a go of it this year.
So firstly, as Jules has humbly asked, please be super-nice and explain what's going wrong here, as I'm not totally sure, and maths trade is a scary, strange thing to us new guys.
THAT SAID, I've had a go at figuring it out. And I get the point that we can:
(a) put in items which we'll ONLY accept cash for
So when it comes time to do the list of wants, we just mark "I want $250 for this game", and none of the games on the geeklist
(b) we are allowed to say "by the way, if your offering cash, you'll need to put $250 in"
This way, you let people kindly know not to waste time putting an offer of $50 in - the maths trade engine simply won't create a match, and we've all wasted time
BUT, it might be that I really want, let's say, a mint condition copy of Magic Realm (pretend it's on the list), and I'm prepared to offer $250 for it. And the owner of the Magic Realm game (let's call him Merlin) might want the game Jules has put up.
So at the end of the trade, it's likely that: (a) I send $250 to Jules (b) Jules sends her game to Merlin (c) Merlin sends Magic Realm to me.
So although I am paying Jules, and I'm also an BorderCon, I'm not the final recipient of her game.
Therefore offering any sort of "I'll be at BorderCon" price incentive is meaningless - if you're lucky enough to be at BorderCon with your maths trade recipient, then lucky you for saving on shipping, but with the "trade loops" that might be created, there is no guarantee you will be, and furthermore, the guy paying in cash may actually paying for a totally different game (I wanted Magic Realm !)
Indeed, I may of said I'll pay $275 for Magic Realm; not sure if that means I end up paying that to Jules, or the engine automatically drops me to $250 ? Equally if I offer $225, I presume no trade match happens, because the engine can't match it to Jules gets the cash amount requested.
Jules - I think the point is that it's quite unlikely that a lot of games might be in at this premium rate. And also, given the multiple participant nature of the Maths trade "loops", offering a discount to BorderCon attendees just doesn't make sense; they won't know who they are until Deep Thought (or whatever the computer is called) spits out the trades.
Hence having cash discounts for BorderCon people might indicate you are not too keen to enter into trade loops, and only keen to do direct sales at BorderCon (for which, as suggested, there might be better channels). I think those who HAVE listed prices are giving an indication of the size of cash offers needed to secure the game. But they also might still get bought up in a game swap too, depending on the want lists.
Oh dear, I think I understand, but not well enough to do much more than ramble. Sorry, might not have helped. But I spent all this time typing, so I'm going to post anyway :)
Someone more intelligent than me, please chip in...

As another sort of newbie (last year was my first maths trade)I think that is a great explanation. As usual the printed word doesn't convey tone - I think everyone is being nice, it's just a matter of pointing out the rules of the game (pun intended). The guys who organise this shindig must do a huge amount of work behind the scenes so it's only fair that the group follows the rules. A part of that is letting the always-welcome-newbies know when they do something that either is against the rules or could be construed as against the rules. I've copped it, I'm sure most of us have. No blood, no foul.
Bottom line - this maths-trade-deal-thingy is awesome and NOTHING like anything else I have come across. It's bound to create confusion for anyone new to it but there's only one way to learn...

People would likely turn a blind eye if it were not for the "Cash only (no trade)" line. There's really no point of putting that line in: it only annoys people :ninja: And it doesn't really mean anything, because (repeating, I know) the person who gets your game may well not be the person who gives you what you want for that game.
If your intent is to only accept cash-in-trade, you can put that in the privacy of your wants list: just having cash as a "want" for that item. If it trades, you'll get what you asked for.
But note that, due to the nature of the trade loops, it is quite possible that someone will "trade up" to it. That shouldn't bother you, because it doesn't affect you. But to take a personal example, I've been in a trade loop where I've got something very nice for something not-so-nice, due to the process that lets you trade a paperclip into a Ferrari: a large series of slowly incrementing trades.
This is why I always put bids in on things I want: because one never knows, my bid might be the link that finishes a long trade loop. And if it doesn't, I haven't lost anything. This is the beauty of the Maths Trade system: you can't get anything you don't want for an item you put up; and you can't give away anything you didn't want to give away for an item you want. As long as you don't make a coding error, that is :blush:
Regards,
David.
If your intention is to not trade any of these games perhaps a maths trade is not the best place to list these. Why not create a geeklist auction or just list them on the BGG marketplace or ebay?
I will explain the customs of the maths trade to Jules.

[q="some_guy"]
You see Math Trades work like this: You send your game to person A, who sends theirs to person B, who sends theirs to Person C.... eventually person X sends you $250. Person X is usually not Person A, hence there needs to be someone willing to put $250 up for another game that is as valuable as yours.
Most likely that ONLY way you'll get this to trade is by a 1-1 swap of game for cash (ie a sale). Hence why use a Math Trade? Just list it on the marketplace or eBay.[/q]
That's what I tried to say (in about 10 paragraphs...) !
Quite a bit more excited about this list now that I've got it clear in my head. Very interesting (mind you, I AM a maths geek as well as a gamer, so I really SHOULD be into this stuff...)
Of course, expect me to have another mental collapse when we come to the "want list" stage...

[q="Friendless"]I will explain the customs of the maths trade to Jules.[/q]
Of course new comers are more than welcome and that is why the [geekurl=/wiki/page/Aussie_Maths_Trade#][b]WIKI[/b][/geekurl] was created. A couple of MTs ago the general opinion was to not include repeated info in the header. I know is a lot to read, but most of the questions are already answered there.

I honestly do not see why it would be a problem for this entry to be in the list.
Jules can state in her want list that she will only accept $250 for it, and it will either trade or it won't. It may be part of a larger loop, or it may end up being a one-for-one trade. So what?
She could have done all that without stating her intention up front, but surely it is helpful/useful - or, at worst, innocuous - to have such information.
I understand that the idea of using the maths trade to sell games - and it seems likely that the clause about asking for less money at Bordercon is info for someone who wants to buy the game before want lists are submitted - is bothersome to many, and hence the suggestion/rule in the header. But that idea always impressed me as misguided. We want to allow cash in the trade so we can "trade" cash for games, but we shouldn't try to "sell" anything? Really?
And, clearly, that suggestion/rule is not enforced. Even if you believe that's how the maths trade should be run, it's hard to imagine strict enforcement of that concept, while still allowing cash, to be anything but a draconian nightmare that would only hurt the trade and the Australian gaming community.
Anyway, with regards to the point that this entry is unlikely to find another item in the trade of the same value: That's probably true; but there has to be a first item for there to be a second, and the first makes the second more likely to appear.

Oh, I do not like this comment paging system! I just discovered a load of conversation I should have seen last night. I agree with what dlow says - putting in the cash only line annoys people and is futile. It will just put people off.
Our system will cope with what Jules is doing. Remember that for any sales, BGG gets a 3% cut.

Can't see the problem myself... No one will be worse off and people are made aware of an opportunity to get a game they may really want.
It may have a slim chance of trading but who cares. The guy who puts up Munchkin for trade and only wants a copy of Hannibal for it is unlikely to trade but no one would comment on that being wrong would they?
Feels a bit like we a game-lawyering over something that really doesn't matter
I should also add that whatever the outcome here I really want to thank the people who organise the maths trade and fully back whatever decisions they make around this issue.

item.comment:
Again - because of the circular nature of trade loops, [i]Trade Only[/i] does not mean that someone who is offering cash can't get this game.
eg I want Dice Duel and offer $x Someone has [i]The Best Game Ever[/I] and is happy to receive $x for it.
If David wants to trade Dice Duel for [i]The Best Game Ever[/I] then a trade loop could form whereby a cash offer receives Dice Duel.

[q="Critical Mass"]Again - because of the circular nature of trade loops, [i]Trade Only[/i] does not mean that someone who is offering cash can't get this game.
eg I want Dice Duel and offer $x Someone has [i]The Best Game Ever[/I] and is happy to receive $x for it.
If David wants to trade Dice Duel for [i]The Best Game Ever[/I] then a trade loop could form whereby a cash offer receives Dice Duel.[/q]
I think David is just stating that [i]he [/i]won't be accepting cash for it.

I think Andrew's comment was intended at the novice math trader rather than being aimed at David's entry. I do think this serves as a good example of certain pieces of information being for certain audiences.
In this case, "trade only" makes it clear to people looking to buy, that David won't be accepting any pre-trade cash offers. But as Andrew points out, it does not mean that there's no point putting a cash offer amount in one's want list for it. These kinds of things can be very counter intuitive. I only really follow how everything works (apart from the internal logic of the algorithm itself, which will forever remain beyond my grasp even if I had the code right in front of me) after seeing the whole process through from beginning to end at least once. But I think small tips and pointers here and there like this can certainly help fill in the gaps for first time math traders.

[q="tiggers"][q="Critical Mass"]Again - because of the circular nature of trade loops, [i]Trade Only[/i] does not mean that someone who is offering cash can't get this game.
eg I want Dice Duel and offer $x Someone has [i]The Best Game Ever[/I] and is happy to receive $x for it.
If David wants to trade Dice Duel for [i]The Best Game Ever[/I] then a trade loop could form whereby a cash offer receives Dice Duel.[/q]
I think David is just stating that [i]he [/i]won't be accepting cash for it.
[/q] This is correct, will edit.

Luke is right. Even as an experienced Maths trader I saw trade only and momentarily thought, "Oh man. I want that but I don't have anything good to trade." Then realized a cash offer could still work. A new Maths trader is pretty likely to just think they can't get this game with cash and new maths traders may be new gamers with more money than games -quite the opposite to many of us.

[q="Critical Mass"]Luke is right. Even as an experienced Maths trader I saw trade only and momentarily thought, "Oh man. I want that but I don't have anything good to trade." Then realized a cash offer could still work. A new Maths trader is pretty likely to just think they can't get this game with cash and new maths traders may be new gamers with more money than games -quite the opposite to many of us.[/q] This is true, sorry. In my head "trade" meant for game or $ and "$x" meant pre-trade sale. Can't assume everyone's head is the same as mine, tho!

I'm interested in what's said here, but I just wanted to say I *hate* the new commenting. At initial glance of the page it appears that there is (was) only one comment. It's not until I page back that I see a whole lot more...

[q="stompy"]I'm interested in what's said here, but I just wanted to say I *hate* the new commenting. At initial glance of the page it appears that there is (was) only one comment. It's not until I page back that I see a whole lot more...[/q] Not to mention that the Hide/Post Comment/page selection bar under every single geeklist item, regardless of whether there's a comment or not feel so much more cluttered.
I know sometimes change can take a while to get used to. In this case though, I just don't see the benefit to user experience at all.
Yep, Andrew's confusion is why I suggest that people don't say trade only or cash only. The program needs to know that, nobody else does.

These have been opened and punched, all the cards have been sleeved in good quality sleeves - and as far as I can tell the game was never played. I do not have the box for Banners of War: all the components are in the original Runewars coffin-box. I bought this game second-hand and this is how it came. It took nearly two hours to check that all the components are present. They are.
This is perfectly ready for play. It is possible to download the second edition rules and use them with this version of the game.
But it is big and heavy. My shipping costs are likely to be significant. Please factor this into consideration if you want to bid for it. Retail for all this is around $200 and there are probably $20 worth of sleeves too. I will not accept less than $120. (NB: I am [i]not[/i] saying this game only available for cash!)

Sweetener: [thing=144557][/thing]. [imageID=1775001] A very neat micro-game of social deduction. This game does not come in a box but instead is sold in a plastic bag. Nevertheless, the cards are all in excellent condition.

Black Box Edition, as pictured.
Includes all the Kickstarter extras: + [thing=107998][/thing] (both I.V and Black Box versions) + [thing=121766][/thing] (both I.V and Black Box versions) + Merchant Bonus Cards (both I.V and Black Box versions) + 5 Mini-Camps ("Travel" version of the player camps - 5 tile thickness 3.5" x 2.5" camps) + Player Mat "risers" - 30 clear plastic feet (so 6 per Camp) + Limited edition badge (with pin) + Limited edition badge (no pin - use as leader token)
The box has the bubbling and dents that were endemic with this version, so it looks used, but it's solid and none of the corners are torn. The contents were played with twice, so are in excellent condition (there is chipping on the Jacks - they came that way; again, a problem with the production of the Black Box Edition).

This is the Deluxe Edition by Looney Labs, which comes with 15 Viewer Necklaces for secretly assigning roles to players. They're pretty cool! The box has been opened, but the Viewer Necklaces are still sealed in their individual bags.
Also comes with:
[thing=38159][/thing] [ImageID=961400] The 2010 edition, which includes the Classic Movie Monsters. Opened and played just a couple times, with the cards sleeved (they are no longer sleeved), so in excellent condition.

This is NOT for the pictured item!
Rather, it is for ALL the miniatures (minus the one Sophie miniature) included in the "Vampire" pledge level of the first Reaper Miniatures Bones Kickstarter campaign - see https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1513061270/reaper-miniatures-bones-an-evolution-of-gaming-min and find the "Vampire" pledge level ($100).
This is about 240 MINIATURES! (I just meticulously counted them and came up with 240, but my count might be slightly off, which is why I say "about".)
There is an astonishing variety of miniatures here! Some are particularly cool (Beholder!) and some are also particularly large (Giants!).
The box these came in has been opened so I could check out the miniatures, but the actual miniatures are each still enclosed in their sealed plastic bags.
But, wait, there's more! ALSO INCLUDES:
Orcpocalypse! (See the set about halfway down the Kickstarter page at the link I gave earlier.) 16 Orc figures, still sealed in their plastic packaging. (The set was supposed to contain 20 figures, but my set is missing the four copies of the one with his sword behind his head.)
I'm open to trade this for a game, but it seems more likely that it will be traded for cash. I'm asking $220 (which includes shipping, of course, as sender pays for shipping).

item.body: [b]Condition:[/b] New, in Shrink [b]Edition[/b]: 1st edition [b]Available:[/b] Trade only

This is a friend's copy, so I am not 100% sure what is contained. I believe it includes the base game and the following expansions (based on my perusal of the cards contained, and my assumption that if some cards from an expansion are included, then all of them are):
Heart of Doom Thornwood Siege Doomgate Legion Dragonspire Wrath of the Elements
I can verify the following:
- excellent condition, packaged in two boxes (Thornwood Siege and Heart of Doom) - all cards sleeved - 207 unique card dividers counted, not including randomisers, settings and reference cards - also contains a couple of bags of bits - all tightly packed, with about 3 inches of foam dividers in each box
[b]Condition:[/b] Opened and played [b]Edition[/b]: 1st edition [b]Available:[/b] Trade
Includes premium sleeves
[b]Condition:[/b] Opened and Played [b]Edition[/b]: 1st edition Z-Man [b]Available:[/b] Trade

Four 12-sided dice, each with a different colour for its numbers, that have the values 1-48 mathematically distributed so that each die is equally likely to roll the highest number (to determine first player) and that continues downward, so each dice is equally likely to be second, third and fourth place, also!
These can be used to determine player order for two-, three- or four-player games, with each player rolling a different die of their choice.
I'm enough of a maths geek to think these are pretty cool. This is an extra copy; I'm keeping mine!
SWEETENER:
